channel.title: Swing positions
channel.description: Hello, I had a question about Swing components. Why does it seem that whenever you add a component like a JLabel or JButton to a frame, it doesn't go into the position you want it to? LIke let's say my frame was 640, 480, and I added a 640x16 JLabel at position 10, 464, it doesn't appear in the screen? I have to set it 10, 430 for it to appear where i want it to. Are there invisible bounds to each component? Or is my math just messed up?

item.title: Swing positions
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:8, topic:312854”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=409279.msg3022247#msg3022247 date=1257661644]

are you sure you are using a “null layout”
ie frame.setLayout(null)

if so, then you can do component.setBounds on every added component. and yes, as nueb35 said you have to consider margin sizes

Yes, frame.setLayout(null) is what i was using because none of the other available layout managers fit my needs. So if I were to do label.setBounds(x, y, width, height) it would be equvalent to label.setLocation(x-offset, y-offset) and label.setSize(width, height)?
[/quote]

i dont think so, i think setBounds just does the same as setSize and setLocation. if you want to skip all of this you can get the content pane, and add it to that because if im not mistaking it has no insets by default[/quote]

Hmm, that does actually make sense. So i would do frame.getContentPane().add(component)?
